question: The reproduction process in which only a single parent is involved is called ________ .
solution:
• Asexual reproduction is the mode of reproduction in which only one parent is involved.
  • It does not involve the fusion of gametes (sperm and egg).
  • Offspring produced are genetically identical (clones) to the parent.
  • Common in unicellular organisms (e.g., amoeba, bacteria) and some plants and animals (e.g., Hydra, yeast).
  • Methods include budding, binary fission, fragmentation, and spore formation.

Additional Information:

  • In vitro fertilization (IVF) is an artificial form of sexual reproduction involving two gametes outside the body.
  • External fertilization involves fusion of gametes outside the body (e.g., in frogs and fishes).
  • Sexual reproduction involves two parents and fusion of male and female gametes.

question: The innermost part of a flower is called the _______ .
solution:
• The innermost part of a flower is called the pistil (also known as the carpel).
  • It is the female reproductive part of the flower and is composed of three main parts:
    • Stigma – receives pollen
    • Style – tube-like structure connecting stigma and ovary
    • Ovary – contains ovules that develop into seeds after fertilization
  • The pistil is centrally located and is essential for sexual reproduction in flowering plants.

Additional Information:

  • Stamens are the male reproductive parts, surrounding the pistil.
  • Petals are colorful structures that attract pollinators.
  • Sepals form the outermost layer and protect the flower bud.

question: Which of the following is not an asexual form of reproduction in plants?
solution:
• Pollination is not a form of asexual reproduction in plants.
  • It is a sexual reproductive process where pollen grains from the anther (male part) are transferred to the stigma (female part) of a flower.
  • Pollination leads to fertilization, resulting in the formation of seeds and fruits.
  • Hence, it involves two parents and gamete fusion, which is characteristic of sexual reproduction.

Additional Information:

  • Spore formation is an asexual method seen in fungi and some lower plants like ferns and mosses.
  • Vegetative propagation is a form of asexual reproduction using parts like roots, stems, or leaves (e.g., potato, onion).
  • Budding is an asexual process in which a new organism develops from an outgrowth (e.g., yeast, Hydra).

question: Productivity of an ecosystem is composed of which of the following?
option_1: Gross productivity and primary productivity
option_2: Primary and secondary productivity
option_3: Net productivity and consumption
option_4: Net primary productivity and gross primary productivity
solution:
• The productivity of an ecosystem is primarily described in terms of gross primary productivity (GPP) and net primary productivity (NPP).
  • GPP refers to the total amount of energy captured by producers (mainly plants) through photosynthesis.
  • NPP is the energy remaining after plants use some of the GPP for respiration; it represents the energy available for herbivores and decomposers.
  • Thus, NPP = GPP – Respiratory Loss (R).
  • These two measures are key indicators of energy flow and biomass production in ecosystems.

Additional Information:

  • Primary productivity includes both gross and net productivity.
  • Secondary productivity refers to energy transfer at consumer levels.
  • Consumption is not directly a measure of productivity, but of energy use.

question: How do the red algae reproduce vegetatively?
solution:
• Red algae (Rhodophyta) reproduce vegetatively through fragmentation.
  • In this method, a part of the thallus breaks off and each fragment develops into a new individual.
  • Fragmentation is a common form of asexual or vegetative reproduction in algae, especially in multicellular marine types.
  • This method ensures rapid multiplication and colonization in favorable aquatic environments.

Additional Information:

  • Fission is seen in unicellular organisms like bacteria and protozoa.
  • Spore formation occurs in fungi and some lower plants.
  • Cutting is an artificial method used in higher plants, not in algae.

question: Which part of a flower is the sticky surface at the top of the pistil, it traps and holds the pollen?
solution:
• The stigma is the sticky surface located at the top of the pistil, the female reproductive part of a flower.
  • Its primary function is to trap and hold pollen grains during pollination.
  • The stigma ensures that the correct type of pollen adheres and begins germination, leading to fertilization.
  • It is connected to the ovary through the style, which guides the pollen tube to the ovules.

Additional Information:

  • Style is the stalk-like structure that connects the stigma to the ovary.
  • Sepals are the outermost floral parts that protect the flower bud before it blooms.
  • Ovary is the enlarged basal portion of the pistil that contains ovules.

question: A type of asexual reproduction in which new plants are produced from roots, stems, leaves and buds are known as:
solution:
• Vegetative propagation is a type of asexual reproduction in which new plants are produced from vegetative parts of the plant like roots, stems, leaves, or buds.
  • This method does not involve seeds and produces genetically identical offspring (clones).
  • Common examples include:
    • Potato (via stem tuber)
    • Bryophyllum (via leaf buds)
    • Onion (via bulb)
  • It occurs naturally and can also be artificially induced in agriculture and horticulture.

Additional Information:

  • Layering propagation is an artificial method where a stem is bent to the ground and covered with soil to form roots.
  • Grafting propagation involves joining parts of two plants.
  • Budding propagation refers to the formation of a new organism from a small outgrowth (seen in Hydra, yeast – not typically in plants).

question:
After fertilization, what will be the future of these parts of a flower—stamens, style, stigma, petal and sepal?

RRB Group-D 27-09-2022 (Shift-I)
option_1: Persistent except sepal shed off in mostly plants
option_2: Stigma, style, stamen shed off except petal and sepal in some plants
option_3: They shed off except sepal which may be persistent in some plants
option_4: Stigma, style shed off except stamen, petal and sepal
solution:
• After fertilization in a flower, most parts such as stamens, style, stigma, and petals usually shed off.
  • The sepal may remain persistent in some plants, protecting the developing fruit or seed.
  • Therefore, the correct option is:

    (c) They shed off except sepal which may be persistent in some plants.

Additional Information:

  • The stamens (male parts) are no longer needed after fertilization and typically fall off.
  • The style and stigma (female parts) also shed after fertilization.
  • Petals often wither and fall after fertilization as they have fulfilled their role in attracting pollinators.
  • Sepals sometimes persist and protect the fruit or seed during development.

question:
After fertilization in plants, the ovule gets converted into:

RRB Group-D 12-09-2022 (Shift-I)
solution:
• After fertilization, the male gamete fuses with the egg cell inside the ovule to form a zygote.
  • The zygote then develops into an embryo.
  • The ovule, which contains the embryo, undergoes changes and matures into a seed.
  • Meanwhile, the ovary of the flower transforms into a fruit enclosing the seeds.
  • Thus, it is the ovule that becomes the seed, not the fruit.

Additional Information:

  • Zygote → first cell formed after fertilization.
  • Embryo → developed form of the zygote inside the seed.
  • Ovule → develops into seed.
  • Ovary → develops into fruit.

question:
Which reproductive parts of the flower contain the germ cells?

RRB Group-D 22-08-2022 (Shift-I)
solution:
• Germ cells are the reproductive cells involved in sexual reproduction.
  • In flowering plants, male germ cells are found in the stamens, specifically in the anther (which produces pollen).
  • Female germ cells are present in the pistil, particularly in the ovule located inside the ovary.
  • Thus, stamens and pistils are the main reproductive parts containing germ cells.

Additional Information:

  • Stamen = Male part = Anther (produces pollen) + Filament
  • Pistil/Carpel = Female part = Stigma + Style + Ovary (contains ovules)
  • Germ cells: Male = Pollen grains; Female = Egg cell in ovule
  • Sepals and petals are non-reproductive and provide protection and attraction.

question:
The reproductive parts of a flower are:

RRB Group-D 20/09/2022 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The reproductive parts of a flower are those directly involved in the formation of gametes and fertilization.
  • The stamens are the male reproductive parts, which produce pollen grains (male germ cells).
  • The pistil (or carpel) is the female reproductive part, which contains the ovary and ovules (female germ cells).
  • Petals and sepals are non-reproductive; they help in protection and pollinator attraction.

Additional Information:

  • Stamen = Anther + Filament → Produces pollen (male gametes)
  • Pistil = Stigma + Style + Ovary → Contains ovules (female gametes)
  • Fertilization occurs when pollen reaches the ovule via the style
  • Together, stamens and pistils make sexual reproduction possible in flowers.

question:
Some plants can also produce new plants from their roots. An example of such a plant is

RRB Group-D 18-08-2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Some plants can reproduce asexually through their roots, forming new plants without seeds.
  • Sweet Potato is an example of a plant that propagates through its adventitious roots.
  • These roots develop buds that can grow into entirely new plants.
  • Other options:
    • Cactus: Reproduces by stem cuttings or seeds.
    • Ginger: Reproduces through underground rhizomes (modified stems), not roots.
    • Bryophyllum: Reproduces through leaf buds, not roots.

Additional Information:

  • Asexual reproduction through roots is called vegetative propagation.
  • Sweet Potato vs. Potato:
    • Sweet Potato: Root tuber
    • Potato: Stem tuber

question:
Which of the following develops into a seedling under appropriate conditions?

RRB Group-D 19-09-2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• A seedling is the young plant that grows from a seed after germination.
  • The part of the seed that actually develops into the seedling is the embryo.
  • The embryo contains the future root (radicle), shoot (plumule), and one or two cotyledons.
  • Other parts of the seed:
    • Endosperm: Provides stored food for the embryo.
    • Seed coat: Protects the seed.
    • Cotyledons: May serve as food source, but do not grow into the plant.

Additional Information:

  • Germination begins when the seed absorbs water under suitable conditions (moisture, temperature, oxygen).
  • The radicle emerges first to form the root, followed by the plumule, which forms the shoot.
  • Hence, only the embryo grows into a seedling.

question:
Which of the following is NOT an example of asexual reproduction?

RRB Group-D 17-08-2022 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Asexual reproduction is a mode of reproduction where offspring are produced without fusion of gametes and involve a single parent.
  • Options (b), (c), and (d) are all natural forms of asexual reproduction:
    • Fragmentation: Seen in organisms like Spirogyra.
    • Binary fission: Common in unicellular organisms like Amoeba and Bacteria.
    • Budding: Seen in Hydra and Yeast.
  • Grafting, however, is an artificial method of plant propagation done by human intervention and involves joining parts of two plants, making it not a natural asexual reproduction.

Additional Information:

  • Grafting is widely used in horticulture for improving plant varieties (e.g., mango, rose).
  • Asexual reproduction is usually faster, and offspring are genetically identical to the parent.

question:
Where can we find a plumule in a plant?

RRB Group-D 26/08/2022 (Shift-I)
option_4: In the root tips
solution:
• The plumule is the part of a seed embryo that develops into the shoot system (stem and leaves) of a plant.
  • It is found inside the seed, as a component of the embryo.
  • It grows upwards after germination, while the radicle (another part of the embryo) grows downwards to form the root.
  • Hence, plumule is present in the seed, not in flower, leaf, or root tip.

Additional Information:

  • Plumule → Future shoot
  • Radicle → Future root
  • Cotyledon → Provides nutrients to embryo during early growth
  • Plumule becomes visible as the first set of leaves after germination.

question:
Which of the following plants produce unisexual flowers?

RRB Group-D 09/09/2022 (Shift-I)
solution:
• Unisexual flowers are those that have either male reproductive parts (stamens) or female reproductive parts (pistil), but not both in the same flower.
  • Watermelon and Papaya are examples of plants that bear unisexual flowers.
  • These plants may have separate male and female flowers on the same plant or on different plants.
  • In contrast:
    • Mustard and Hibiscus produce bisexual flowers, meaning both stamens and pistils are present in the same flower.

Additional Information:

  • Unisexual flowers → Only one reproductive organ (either stamen or pistil)
  • Bisexual flowers → Both stamen and pistil in one flower
  • Other examples of unisexual plants: corn, cucumber
  • Unisexual flowers help promote cross-pollination.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a component of the male reproductive part of flower?

RRB Group-D 08/09/2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The male reproductive part of a flower is called the stamen, which consists of:
    • Anther – produces pollen grains (male gametes)
    • Filament – a stalk that holds the anther
  • Pollen is not a structural part but is produced by the anther, so it is also considered a product of the male part.
  • Style, on the other hand, is a part of the female reproductive organ (pistil/carpel). It connects the stigma to the ovary and allows passage of pollen tube.

Additional Information:

  • Stamen (Male part) = Anther + Filament
  • Pistil/Carpel (Female part) = Stigma + Style + Ovary
  • Style guides the pollen tube to the ovary for fertilization
  • Only option (d) Style does not belong to the male part.

question:
Which of the following is the female reproductive part of a flower?

RRB Group-D 08/09/2022 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The female reproductive part of a flower is called the pistil (also known as carpel).
  • The pistil is composed of three main parts:
    • Stigma – receives pollen grains
    • Style – tube-like structure connecting stigma to ovary
    • Ovary – contains ovules (female gametes)
  • Other options:
    • Sepal: Protective leaf-like structure that covers the flower bud
    • Petal: Colored part that attracts pollinators
    • Stamen: Male reproductive part (includes anther and filament)

Additional Information:

  • Fertilization occurs when pollen reaches the ovule inside the ovary via the style.
  • After fertilization, ovule becomes seed and ovary becomes fruit.

question:
Which of the following types of asexual reproduction is shown by the bread mould Rhizopus?

RRB Group-D 05/09/2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Rhizopus, commonly known as bread mould, reproduces asexually by spore formation.
  • In this process, the fungus produces tiny sporangia (spore cases) on stalk-like structures.
  • These sporangia burst and release spores, which are capable of growing into new individuals when they land on a suitable surface (like moist bread).
  • Other options:
    • Budding: Seen in yeast and Hydra
    • Regeneration: Seen in planaria or starfish
    • Fission: Common in unicellular organisms like Amoeba and Bacteria

Additional Information:

  • Spores are lightweight and airborne, allowing wide dispersal.
  • Under moist and warm conditions, spores germinate quickly.
  • Spore formation is a rapid and efficient mode of reproduction in fungi.

question:
Which of the following are bisexual flowers?

RRB Group-D – 18/09/2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Bisexual flowers are those that contain both male (stamens) and female (pistil) reproductive organs in the same flower.
  • Hibiscus and Mustard are classic examples of bisexual flowers, as each of their flowers has stamens and a pistil, enabling self-pollination or cross-pollination.
  • In contrast:
    • Watermelon and Papaya produce unisexual flowers (male and female flowers are separate).

Additional Information:

  • Bisexual flower = Has both stamens and pistil in one flower (also called perfect flower)
  • Examples: Hibiscus, Mustard, Rose, Sunflower
  • Unisexual flower = Has only stamens or pistil
  • Examples: Papaya, Watermelon, Corn

question:
Which type of reproduction allows greater variation to be generated?

RRB Group-D 09-10-2018 (Shift-II)

RRB Group-D 20-09-2018 (Shift-I)

RRB ALP & Tec. (21-08-18 Shift-I)
solution:
• Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of male and female gametes from two different individuals.
  • This process leads to genetic recombination, resulting in greater variation in the offspring.
  • Variations are important for evolution and adaptation to changing environments.
  • In contrast:
    • Binary fission and Multiple fission are forms of asexual reproduction, producing clones (genetically identical offspring).
    • Asexual reproduction does not involve gamete fusion, so it does not generate much variation.

Additional Information:

  • Greater genetic variation from sexual reproduction increases chances of survival of the species.
  • It allows for natural selection to act upon diverse traits.
  • Asexual reproduction is faster, but lacks diversity.

question:
The roots, stems and leaves of some plants grow new plants through process of .............

RRB Group-D 26-09-2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The process by which roots, stems, and leaves of certain plants give rise to new plants is called vegetative propagation.
  • It is a type of asexual reproduction where a vegetative part of the plant (not involving seeds) develops into a new plant.
  • Examples of vegetative propagation:
    • Stem: Potato (via stem tubers), Ginger (via rhizomes)
    • Root: Sweet potato (root tubers)
    • Leaf: Bryophyllum (leaf buds)
  • Other options:
    • Fission and Multiple fission occur in unicellular organisms (e.g., Amoeba, Plasmodium)
    • Regeneration: Formation of a whole organism from a part, seen in planaria or starfish, not typical in plants

Additional Information:

  • Vegetative propagation is fast, reliable, and produces genetically identical offspring (clones).
  • Used in horticulture for producing large numbers of plants quickly (e.g., sugarcane, rose, banana).

question:
Which of the following method of reproduction in which new plant is genetically identical to the parent plant?

RRB Group-D 26-11-2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Vegetative reproduction is a form of asexual reproduction in which a new plant grows from a vegetative part of the parent plant such as root, stem, or leaf.
  • Since it does not involve fusion of gametes, the offspring is genetically identical (a clone) to the parent plant.
  • Other options:
    • Regeneration: Involves growth of a whole organism from a part; not always produces identical genetic copies.
    • Fission: Occurs in unicellular organisms like Amoeba; not typical in plants.
    • Sexual reproduction: Involves fusion of male and female gametes; leads to genetic variation, not identical offspring.

Additional Information:

  • Vegetative reproduction is fast, maintains parental traits, and is commonly used in agriculture and horticulture.
  • Examples: Potato (stem tuber), Sweet Potato (root tuber), Bryophyllum (leaf), Ginger (rhizome)

question:
Which of the following methods of reproduction is adopted by unicellular organisms?

RRB Group-D
solution:
• Unicellular organisms (organisms made of a single cell) commonly reproduce by fission.
  • In fission, the parent cell splits into two (binary fission) or more (multiple fission) daughter cells.
  • This process is asexual and results in genetically identical offspring.
  • Examples:
    • Binary fission: Amoeba, Bacteria
    • Multiple fission: Plasmodium (malarial parasite)
  • Other options:
    • Regeneration: Seen in multicellular organisms like planaria
    • Fragmentation: In multicellular algae like Spirogyra
    • Budding: Seen in organisms like yeast and Hydra (mostly multicellular)

Additional Information:

  • Fission is a rapid, efficient, and natural method of reproduction for unicellular life forms.
  • It does not require gametes or a mate.

question:
........ spreads through the stem.

RRB Group-D 10-12-2018 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Rose.
  • Rose reproduces or spreads through the stem by a method known as vegetative propagation, specifically stem cutting.
  • In this method, a portion of the stem is cut and planted in soil, where it develops roots and grows into a new plant, genetically identical to the parent.
  • Other options:
    • Bryophyllum: Spreads through leaves (leaf buds)
    • Bryophylla: Incorrect/invalid spelling (likely a mistaken form of Bryophyllum)
    • Tamarind: Typically grows from seeds, not stem propagation

Additional Information:

  • Vegetative propagation by stem is used for plants like rose, money plant, grapevine, etc.
  • It ensures faster reproduction and retains parental characteristics.

question:
In a plant, the seed contains the embryo which develops into a seedling under appropriate conditions. This process is known as:

RRB NTPC 12-01-2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
solution:
• The process in which a seed starts to grow and develop into a seedling under favorable conditions (water, oxygen, warmth) is called germination.
  • During germination, the embryo inside the seed becomes active and begins to grow:
    • Radicle (root) emerges first
    • Plumule (shoot) comes out next
  • Other options:
    • Pollination: Transfer of pollen from anther to stigma
    • Cross-pollination: Pollen transfer between different plants
    • Transpiration: Loss of water vapor from plant leaves

Additional Information:

  • Conditions necessary for germination:
    • Water – to activate enzymes
    • Oxygen – for energy (respiration)
    • Warmth – suitable temperature for enzyme activity
  • Germination ends when the seedling can perform photosynthesis on its own.

question:
Which of the following plants has 'hidden reproductive organs'?

RRB NTPC 12-01-2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
solution:
• The term "hidden reproductive organs" refers to plants whose reproductive structures are not visible externally or are enclosed within the body.
  • These types of plants are classified as cryptogams, which include algae, bryophytes, and pteridophytes.
  • Marsilea is a pteridophyte, and like all pteridophytes, it reproduces via spores and has hidden reproductive organs (no flowers or seeds).
  • Other options:
    • Ipomoea: A flowering plant (angiosperm) with visible reproductive organs
    • Deodar and Pinus: Gymnosperms, have exposed seeds and cones, not hidden organs

Additional Information:

  • Cryptogams = "crypto" (hidden) + "gamy" (reproduction)
  • Marsilea is a fern-like aquatic plant that reproduces by spores
  • Angiosperms and gymnosperms have distinct reproductive structures, unlike cryptogams

question:
Parthenocarpy is defined as:

RRB ALP & Tec. (21-08-18 Shift-I)
option_1: Development of roots with fertilization
option_2: Development of fruits with fertilization
option_3: Development of roots without fertilization
option_4: Development of fruits without fertilization
solution:
• Parthenocarpy refers to the formation of fruits without fertilization of ovules.
  • Such fruits are usually seedless, e.g., banana, grapes, and pineapple.
  • It occurs naturally or can be induced by applying growth hormones like auxins.
  • Parthenocarpy is useful in agriculture for producing seedless varieties that are more palatable and marketable.

Additional Information:

  • Fertilization involves the fusion of male and female gametes; parthenocarpic fruits bypass this step.
  • Parthenogenesis, on the other hand, is the development of an embryo without fertilization, not fruit.

question:
Which of the following serves as a nutritive tissue for the growing embryo?

RRB ALP & Tec. (09-08-18 Shift-II)
solution:
• Endosperm is a tissue produced inside the seeds of most flowering plants following fertilization.
  • It serves as a nutritive tissue that supplies food to the developing embryo.
  • It is usually rich in starch, but may also contain oils and proteins.
  • In many cereals (like wheat, rice, maize), the endosperm is the main storage tissue used during seed germination.

Additional Information:

  • The zygote develops into the embryo.
  • The ovule becomes the seed after fertilization.
  • The ovary develops into the fruit.

question:
In which of the flowering plants are buds produced in the notches along the leaf margin?

RRB ALP & Tec. (10-08-18 Shift-I)
solution:
• In Bryophyllum, small buds are formed in the notches along the leaf margins.
  • These buds can develop into new plants, making it a common example of vegetative propagation.
  • This method allows asexual reproduction, where no gametes are involved.
  • Each detached bud can grow into a genetically identical plant.

Additional Information:

  • Bryophyta is a group of non-vascular plants like mosses, not a flowering plant.
  • Banana reproduces through underground rhizomes, not leaf buds.
  • Rose commonly propagates through stem cuttings, not leaf margins.

question:
Which of the following is not a pollinating agent for cross pollination?

RRB ALP & Tec. (13-08-18 Shift-I)
solution:
• Pollinating agents are external factors that help in transferring pollen from the anther of one flower to the stigma of another (cross-pollination).
  • Common pollinating agents include:
    • Wind (Anemophily)
    • Water (Hydrophily)
    • Animals (Zoophily), like bees, birds, bats, insects
  • Plants themselves do not act as pollinating agents; they are recipients or sources of pollen, not the medium of transfer.

Additional Information:

  • Cross-pollination increases genetic diversity.
  • Self-pollination, in contrast, does not require external agents.
  • Some plants have adaptations like colorful petals or nectar to attract pollinators.

question:
Which part of the plant is specialized to reproduce asexually in a Runner (grass)?

RRB Group-D 10-12-2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• In runner-type plants like grass, stems are modified for asexual reproduction.
  • These are horizontal stems (called runners) that grow above the ground and give rise to new plants at nodes.
  • Each node forms roots and shoots, developing into an independent plant.
  • This process is a form of vegetative propagation.

Additional Information:

  • Flower is involved in sexual reproduction.
  • Roots may sometimes help in asexual reproduction (e.g., sweet potato) but not in runners.
  • Leaves help in vegetative propagation in some plants like Bryophyllum, but not in runners.

question:
The transfer of pollen from the anthers of one flower to the stigma of the same plant is called _______.

RRB Group-D 11-10-2018 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The process of transferring pollen grains from the anther to the stigma is known as pollination.
  • When this transfer occurs within the same plant (either same flower or a different flower on the same plant), it is called self-pollination.
  • This is a key step in sexual reproduction in flowering plants.
  • Pollination can be assisted by wind, insects, water, etc., depending on the plant species.

Additional Information:

  • Regeneration is the process of regrowing lost body parts or tissues.
  • Transpiration refers to the loss of water vapor from plant leaves.
  • Sexual reproduction includes pollination but also involves fusion of gametes to form a zygote.

question:
Through which of the following methods, plants can be grown by single parent plant in disease-free condition?

RRB Group-D 01-10-2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Tissue culture is a technique where new plants are grown from a few cells or tissues of a single parent plant under sterile (disease-free) laboratory conditions.
  • It is a method of asexual reproduction, producing genetically identical (clonal) offspring.
  • This method is widely used to propagate plants rapidly, especially those that are hard to grow through seeds.
  • It ensures disease-free, high-quality plants useful in agriculture and horticulture.

Additional Information:

  • Regeneration refers to the regrowth of parts, not necessarily under sterile conditions.
  • Spore formation is common in fungi and some non-flowering plants, but not ideal for disease-free cultivation.
  • Sexual reproduction involves genetic variation and is not typically used when uniformity and disease-free plants are desired.

question:
Plant that does not grow by vegetative propagation:

RRB Group-D 20-09-2018 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Vegetative propagation is an asexual method of plant reproduction where new plants grow from parts like roots, stems, or leaves of the parent plant.
  • Banana propagates through rhizomes (underground stems).
  • Rose propagates through stem cuttings.
  • Orange can be propagated vegetatively via grafting or budding.
  • Papaya, however, is not propagated vegetatively; it typically grows through seeds, which makes it the correct answer.

Additional Information:

  • Vegetative propagation is faster and helps preserve the genetic identity of the parent plant.
  • It is widely used in horticulture for uniform quality and disease resistance.

question:
Asexual reproduction occurs in –

RRB Group-D 27-09-2018 (Shift-I)
option_4: Under developed animals and plants
solution:
• Asexual reproduction is a mode of reproduction where offspring are produced from a single parent without the fusion of gametes.
  • It commonly occurs in:
    • Plants – via methods like vegetative propagation, spore formation, and budding.
    • Underdeveloped animals – such as Hydra, Amoeba, Planaria, etc., using budding, binary fission, or regeneration.
  • Highly developed animals (like mammals, birds) do not reproduce asexually.

Additional Information:

  • Asexual reproduction results in genetically identical offspring (clones).
  • It is faster than sexual reproduction and does not require a mate.

question:
Pollination is followed by……….

RRB Group-D 05-12-2018 (Shift-I)
solution:
• Pollination is the process of transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of a flower.
  • After pollination, the next step is fertilization, where the male gamete from the pollen fuses with the female gamete (egg cell) in the ovule.
  • This fusion forms a zygote, which later develops into an embryo inside the seed.
  • Thus, fertilization always follows pollination in sexual reproduction in flowering plants.

Additional Information:

  • Differentiation is the process where cells become specialized, not directly linked to pollination.
  • Spore formation occurs in lower plants like fungi, not after pollination.
  • Transpiration is the loss of water vapor through plant leaves and is unrelated to reproduction.

question:
Which of the following reproduce through stem of the plant?

RRB Group-D 12-11-2018 (Shift-I)
solution:
• Rose reproduces vegetatively through stem cuttings. A piece of the stem with a node is planted in soil, and it develops into a new plant. This is a common method in gardening and horticulture.
  • Bryophyllum reproduces through leaf buds, not the stem. Tiny buds develop along the leaf margins and grow into new plants.
  • Tamarind is usually propagated by seeds or grafting, not by stem.
  • Bryophyta (like mosses) reproduce via spores, not by stem propagation.

Correct Answer:(b) Rose

question:
Which of the following is not a mode of asexual reproduction?

RRB NTPC 04.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage 1st
solution:
• Asexual reproduction involves a single parent and does not involve the fusion of gametes.
  • Budding, Binary Fission, and Fragmentation are all types of asexual reproduction:
    • Budding: Seen in organisms like yeast and hydra.
    • Binary fission: Common in bacteria and amoeba.
    • Fragmentation: Seen in algae like Spirogyra and some worms.
  • Cross fertilization, on the other hand, is a sexual reproduction process where gametes from two different individuals fuse to form a zygote.

Additional Information:

  • Asexual reproduction is usually faster and does not lead to genetic variation.
  • Sexual reproduction (like cross fertilization) leads to genetic variation and is seen in higher organisms.

question:
Pollination by wind is called:

RRB NTPC 29.03.2016 (Shift-I) Stage 1st
solution:
• Pollination is the transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of a flower.
  • When wind is the agent that carries the pollen, it is called Anemophily.
  • The term "Anemo" means wind in Greek.
  • Anemophilous plants usually produce light, dry pollen and have feathery stigmas to catch airborne pollen.

Additional Information:

  • Hydrophily – pollination by water (e.g., Vallisneria)
  • Entomophily – pollination by insects (not in options)
  • Zoophily – pollination by animals (general term)
  • Pollinophily and Herbophily are not standard biological terms.
